conclusion: Apply principles of motion in a magnetic field, focusing on conservation of energy and forces on the conductor rod.
Identify given values: mass \( m \), resistance per unit length \( r \), height difference \( l \), gravity \( g \).
Conductor rod remains horizontal and maintains good contact with rails; forces are magnetic and gravitational.
Magnetic force \( F = BIL \) where \( I \) is the current in the conductor.
Magnetic force \( F \) equals weight of conductor rod, \( F = mg \).
Total force on rod is sum of magnetic and gravitational forces: \( F_{\text{total}} = mg + BIL \).
Net force is zero since rod remains horizontal: \( mg + BIL = 0 \).
Velocity \( v \) found using equation of motion: \( v^2 = v_0^2 + 2gl \left( \frac{mg}{BL} \right) \).
Rod starts from rest, \( v_0 = 0 \): \( v^2 = 2gl \left( \frac{mg}{BL} \right) \).
Substitute given values \( m = 1 \, \text{kg}, B = 1 \, \text{T}, l = 1 \, \text{m} \): \( v = \sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 1 \times 1} \).
Final velocity \( v \) of conductor rod at constant speed is approximately \( 4.47 \, \text{m/s} \).
